description: From Latin auspicatus, past participle of auspicari "to take auspices", from auspex "bird seer", "augur", a contraction of avispex; avis "bird" + specere, spicere, "to view".

adjectives.description: auspicate (comparative more auspicate, superlative most auspicate)

verbs.description: auspicate (third-person singular simple present auspicates, present participle auspicating, simple past and past participle auspicated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give a favorable turn to in commencing; to inaugurate; -- a sense derived from the Roman practice of taking the auspicium, or inspection of birds, before undertaking any important business.
